Award.AbstractNarration:
Earth scientists today have unprecedented online access to collected data on rock compositions. This work aims to expand the capabilities and access to modeling tools whereby such data can be compared to hypotheses about the Earth. The alphaMELTS software package provides a flexible, powerful, easy-to-use interface to a set of successful models and algorithms that apply the theory of classical thermodynamics to understanding melting and crystallization of igneous rocks. This grant will enable the creation of the next generation of the software, interaction with users to implement requested features and support their modeling efforts, testing and demonstration of new features, optimization of the package for use in teaching, and publication of its educational features to encourage wide adoption. The award will fund a Database of MELTS Examples (DOME) to facilitate quick start-up and reproducibility of results; new solid solution models; a family of routines for seamless incorporation of alphaMELTS functionality into any Fortran, C++, Matlab or Python code; Visualization and analysis tools through coupling to MATLABTM; and more.

This award will enable significant outreach by alphaMELTS developers to the broad geological instruction and research communities. It will fund two "MELTS camp" short courses to introduce new users to the software and demonstrate its capabilities. All software developed under this work will be released free of charge for use by the community and support under this award will enable dynamic interaction with the user community for support and implementation of user-requested features.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The NSF geoinformatics program supports the use of advanced computing that enables geoscience researchers to carry out new, high-impact research, through access to data or modeling tools. The alphaMELTS package is a modeling environment that allows petrologists and geochemists to study the melting and crystallization of igneous rocks in an internally consistent thermodynamic framework (thermodynamics is the branch of science that predicts the behavior of chemical and physical systems by monitoring the influence of energy on large numbers of atoms). For example, as temperature increases or presure decreases on a rock, thermodynamics can describe when it begins to melt, what minerals dissolve into the melt in what order, how the chemical composition of the melt and minerals change, and more. When such processes are modeled using thermodynamics, we have confidence that the predictions will apply to nature and we can ask hard questions about the relationship between energy and matter in rock systems. However, carrying out such models in practice requires a lot of computing, because the systems have many dimensions and complex functional forms.

Over the three-and-a-half years that this award supported the alphaMELTS development team, we released three new versions of the software, expanded out user base from about 400 to over 1200, offered workshops that educated 210 scientists (ranging from undergraduate students to senior faculty) in how to use the software,  and built tools to connect alphaMELTS to other commonly used software tools to increase its power. The alphaMELTS model can now be embedded in large-scale flow calculations that use fluid dynamics to model the motions of plate tectonics, the turbulence in magma chambers, and more.
